__data__.text: The geology of central southern Turkey and northwestern Syria is shaped by the interaction of the African, Arabian, and Anatolian plates. The Dead Sea Transform (DST) marks the boundary between the African and Arabian plates, accommodating the northward movement of Arabia relative to Africa. The DST connects to the East Anatolian Fault (EAF) at the Marash Triple Junction, which forms the boundary between the African and Anatolian plates and extends to the Cyprus arc via the Latakia Ridge. The EAF is a 700 km-long left-lateral strike-slip fault, subdivided into seven segments with decreasing slip rates from northeast to southwest. A northern strand of the EAF also exists, including several fault segments. The Sürgü-Çardak Fault is an east-west striking fault north of the EAF's main strand.

The northern strand of the Dead Sea Transform (DST) includes the Sürgü-Çardak Fault, which is an east-west striking fault with a length of 160 km, divided into two segments (Sürgü and Çardak). The Çardak segment has an estimated slip rate of 2.5 mm/year. The DST in the northern region is divided into several segments, with some disagreement among scientists about which faults belong to the DST or the East Anatolian Fault (EAF). Seven DST segments have been identified in Turkey and neighboring Syria, including Afrin, Sermada, Armanaz, Hacıpaşa, Yesemek, Sakçagöz, and Narlı. The EAF has experienced significant earthquakes in recent centuries, with a notable recurrence interval of approximately 150 years for M 6.8-7.0 earthquakes on the Palu and Pütürge segments in the east. The Sürgü-Çardak Fault has low seismic activity, with only one recorded earthquake (M 6.8) in 1544.

The text discusses the seismic activity and earthquake history of the northern Dead Sea Transform (DST) and the East Anatolian Fault (EAF). The EAF has experienced significant earthquakes, with recurrence intervals of 150 years for M 6.8-7.0 earthquakes on the Palu and Pütürge segments in the east. The Pazarcık and Amanos segments in the west have longer recurrence intervals of 237-772 years and 414-917 years, respectively, for M 7.0-7.4 earthquakes. A 2002 study identified two seismic gaps on the EAF with high potential for future earthquakes, one in Elazığ and Bingöl, and another in Kahramanmaraş. The DST has also had large historical earthquakes, including events in 115, 526, 587, 1138, 1170, and 1822, which resulted in numerous fatalities. A recent earthquake sequence occurred in 2020, with the first and largest earthquake measuring Mww 7.8 and Mw 7.8, according to the USGS and GCMT, respectively. It had an epicenter near the border with Syria.

The text describes the details of two significant earthquakes that occurred in the northern Dead Sea Transform (DST) and the East Anatolian Fault (EAF) in 2020. The first earthquake had a magnitude of Mww 7.8 (USGS) or Mw 7.7 (KOERI) and an epicenter near the border with Syria. The second earthquake struck 95 km northeast of the first one, with a magnitude of Mww 7.5 (USGS), Mw 7.6 (KOERI), or Mw 7.7 (Geoscope and GCMT). The hypocenter of both earthquakes was at a depth of 5-10 km, and they had a strike-slip faulting mechanism. These earthquakes were the strongest in Turkey in over 2,000 years, with moment magnitudes of Mw 7.95 ± 0.013 and Mw 7.86 ± 0.012, respectively. Over 570 aftershocks were recorded within 24 hours of the first earthquake, and over 30,000 were recorded by May 2023. An aftershock measuring Mww 6.7 occurred about 11 minutes after the mainshock.

The two significant earthquakes that hit the northern Dead Sea Transform and the East Anatolian Fault in 2020 were the largest in Turkey in over 2,000 years. The first earthquake, with a magnitude of Mw 7.8, triggered over 570 aftershocks within the first 24 hours and over 30,000 by May 2023. A notable aftershock of Mww 6.7 occurred approximately 11 minutes after the mainshock. The second earthquake, with a magnitude of Mww 7.5, had its own aftershock sequence, including two mb 6.0 aftershocks, and thousands of associated aftershocks along an east-west trend corresponding to the Çardak Fault. The seismic source models for the first earthquake by the USGS indicate three fault segments with varying lengths, widths, strikes, and dips, with the mainshock producing a maximum slip of 11.2 m along the second segment.

The first earthquake, with a magnitude of Mw 7.8, had a maximum slip of 11.2 m (37 ft) along Segment 2 in the Sakarya area of Kahramanmaraş Province, and another large slip of 4.96 m (16.3 ft) further northeast. The second earthquake, magnitude Mw 7.7, involved three major fault segments with varying dimensions and maximum displacement of 11.4 m (37 ft) on the first segment. The first earthquake ruptured approximately 370 km (230 mi) of the East Anatolian Fault (EAF), with a maximum slip of 9 m (30 ft) along the Pazarcık segment. The second earthquake had slip concentrated within the Çardak Fault, shallower and more compact than the first earthquake's slip. The section of the EAF between the two major earthquakes, the Pütürge segment, may indicate a seismic gap.

The first earthquake, with a magnitude of Mw 7.8, had a significant slip of 11.2 m (37 ft) along the Sakarya section of the Kahramanmaraş Province, and another slip of 4.96 m (16.3 ft) further northeast. The second earthquake, magnitude Mw 7.7, had a major slip of 11.4 m (37 ft) on its first segment. The first earthquake ruptured approximately 370 km (230 mi) of the East Anatolian Fault (EAF), while the second earthquake's slip was more concentrated within the Çardak Fault, at shallower depths. A seismic gap may be present in the Pütürge segment between the two major earthquakes. The Mw 6.4 aftershock had a rupture area of 25 km (16 mi) × 25 km (16 mi) and a peak slip of 0.93 m (3 ft 1 in) at 8.3 km (5.2 mi) depth. The first earthquake increased stress on the Çardak–Sürgü Fault and the Hatay Fault, potentially triggering the Mw 6.4 aftershock. The initial rupture occurred on the Narlı Fault, then propagated unilaterally northward until it reached the Pazarcık segment of the EAF, where it continued bilaterally to the northeast and southwest. The initial rupture transitioned to supershear after propagating about 19.5 km (12.1 mi) away from the epicenter along the Narlı Fault.

The first earthquake, with a magnitude of Mw 7.8, initially ruptured at oblique-normal faulting and transitioned to supershear speed after propagating about 19.5 km (12.1 mi) along the Narlı Fault. The total rupture length was approximately 560 km (350 mi), extending to the Ekernek and Amanos segments. The northeastern rupture ended after 55 seconds, while the southwestern rupture ended near Antakya after around 80 seconds. A Mw 6.8 aftershock possibly occurred along the Sakçagöz Fault. The second earthquake, magnitude Mw 7.7, initiated on the Çardak–Sürgü Fault Zone and propagated bilaterally along the Çardak and Sürgü segments, continuing eastwards to Malatya along the Doğanşehir Fault Zone, with a total rupture length of 160 km (99 mi).

The second earthquake involved a bilateral rupture along the Çardak and Sürgü segments, continuing eastwards to Malatya along the Doğanşehir Fault Zone, with a total rupture length of 160 km (99 mi). The rupture moved at different velocities in different directions, with the westward-propagating rupture occurring at supershear velocity and the eastward-propagating rupture at subshear velocity. The earthquake lasted around 35 seconds, and an aftershock of magnitude Mw 6.4 occurred along the Hatay Fault. Surface ruptures were observed along the northeast-southwest striking fault, extending from north of Antakya, Hatay Province towards Pazarcık, Kahramanmaraş Province and Gölbaşı, Adıyaman Province. The longer of the two surface ruptures, produced by the first earthquake, measured 320 km (200 mi), while the second earthquake produced 150 km (93 mi) of surface rupture. The surface ruptures caused damage to the westernmost part of Hatay Airport and a major canal, leading to flooding in parts of the Amik Valley. Field observations indicate a maximum displacement of 7.3 m (24 ft) on the surface.

The second earthquake featured surface ruptures extending north from Pazarcık to Nurdağı, with significant displacements ranging from 2.5 to 5 meters (8 ft 2 in to 16 ft). The westernmost part of Hatay Airport and a major canal were damaged due to surface ruptures, causing flooding in the Amik Valley, formerly Lake Amik. Large ground acceleration values, exceeding 1 g, were recorded in several areas, with the highest value of 2.212 g at a station in Pazarcık Belediyesi Parkı, resulting in severe damage to the surrounding town.

The second earthquake had surface ruptures causing significant displacements and damage to the westernmost part of Hatay Airport, a canal, and the surrounding town of Pazarcık. Large ground acceleration values, exceeding 1 g, were recorded in a wide area around the epicenter, with the highest value of 2.212 g at a station in Pazarcık Belediyesi Parkı. The maximum Mercalli intensity (MMI) of the mainshock reached MMI XI-XII (Extreme) near the epicenter and in Antakya, and MMI X (Extreme) along the fault rupture to Antakya. MMI IX-X (Violent-Extreme) was observed in Kahramanmaraş and İskenderun, and MMI VIII-IX (Severe-Violent) in Malatya and Adıyaman. Geological effects such as liquefaction and lateral spreading were identified in the Amik Valley, Orontes River plain, Samandağ, and Gölbaşı, causing extensive damage in İskenderun.

The second earthquake caused significant damage in high-elevation areas due to snow cover and lack of satellite observations. Liquefaction and lateral spreading were observed in Samandağ and Lake Gölbaşı, leading to submerged lakeshores and damaged buildings. İskenderun experienced extensive damage from subsidence, liquefaction, lateral spreading, flooding, and a small tsunami. Despite the inland epicenter, a tsunami was recorded in the Mediterranean Sea, with small waves along the Turkish and Cypriot coasts. In Turkey, there were over 50,000 deaths, 297 missing persons, and 107,000 injuries across 11 provinces. Approximately 15.73 million people and 4 million buildings were affected, with around 345,000 apartments destroyed. Over 2 million residents were evacuated, and more than 20% of Turkey's agriculture production was impacted. The United Nations reported significant damage to crops, livestock, fisheries, aquaculture, and rural infrastructure.

The earthquake caused significant damage to buildings and infrastructure, affecting over 15.73 million people and 4 million buildings, with approximately 345,000 apartments destroyed. More than 2 million residents were evacuated, and over 20% of Turkey's agriculture production was impacted. The United Nations reported extensive damage to rural infrastructure and buildings, including at least 516 university buildings and 968 mosques. The Turkish government's damage assessment revealed the need to demolish at least 61,722 buildings, with a high concentration in certain provinces. Recovery efforts uncovered body parts in the rubble, and several buildings, including historical sites and mosques, were damaged or destroyed. In Malatya, two hotels collapsed, and 11 people died in Akçadağ due to earthquake-related causes.

The earthquake resulted in significant damage to buildings and infrastructure, including the destruction of 25 mosques and damage to 420 others in the city. Two hotels in Malatya collapsed, and several historical sites, such as Gaziantep Castle and Şirvani Mosque, were severely damaged. In various cities, numerous buildings were demolished or severely damaged, leading to mass casualties and the creation of mass graves. Airports in the region, including Gaziantep Oğuzeli and Hatay, experienced disruptions in service. The collapse of a luxury apartment building in Hatay trapped and killed hundreds of people. The earthquake also caused extensive damage to homes and buildings in Antakya, Kırıkhan, and İskenderun districts.

The earthquake caused extensive destruction in Antakya, with 70% of homes and 6,369 buildings collapsing, and many more severely damaged. Notably, the Rönesans Rezidans apartment's collapse trapped and killed hundreds. Infrastructure in the region also suffered, with the runway of Hatay Airport splitting and uplifting, and several hospitals, a police station, and historical sites being destroyed. Multiple buildings in various districts, including Güzelburç, Cebrail, Defne, Reyhanlı, Arsuz, Kumlu, and Payas, were destroyed or severely damaged. In İskenderun, a large fire at the port forced its closure for several days.

The fire at İskenderun port, reignited multiple times, was finally extinguished on 10 February, causing a three-month suspension of operations and destroying 3,670 containers. The earthquake resulted in significant damage in various districts, including Erzin, Samandağ, Hassa, Altınözü, Yayladağı, Belen, and Dörtyol. Mass burials took place in Kahramanmaraş for over 5,000 bodies, with an expectation to reach 10,000. Around 75% of the city's buildings were damaged or destroyed, and 924 people died in Elbistan, with an estimated 2,000 buildings destroyed. Almost all single-story buildings were decimated in Ordekdede, a village in Pazarcik District. Flooding, building collapses, and severe damage occurred in multiple areas, resulting in thousands of deaths and injuries, and displacing many residents.

After the earthquake, a city official predicted that a mass grave in Kahramanmaraş would eventually hold 10,000 bodies. The disaster caused significant damage to 75% of the city's buildings, with 924 deaths and 1,825 injuries in Elbistan alone. In Ordekdede, a village in Pazarcik District, almost all single-story buildings were destroyed, and none of the 140 houses remained structurally sound. Other villages and towns, such as Ekinözü, Afşin, Ericek, Nurhak, Türkoğlu, and various districts in Adıyaman Province, experienced extensive building collapses, severe damage, and high death tolls. In Adıyaman Province, over 20,000 buildings and 56,600 apartments were destroyed, causing the death of up to 10% of the population. The disaster also severely damaged Gölbaşı's infrastructure, with 695 deaths and over 400 injuries.

Post-earthquake, numerous villages and towns experienced significant destruction, including Harmanlı in Gölbaşı District, where 80-90% of the village was destroyed. Gölbaşı's infrastructure was severely damaged, resulting in 695 deaths and over 400 injuries. Diyarbakır Province saw 8,086 buildings damaged, including the UNESCO World Heritage Site of Diyarbakır Fortress and Hevsel Gardens. In Şanlıurfa Province, at least 466 buildings were heavily damaged, and the Pool of Abraham was affected. Osmaniye and Kilis Provinces also suffered building destruction, while Bingöl, Samsun, and Muş Provinces experienced less severe damage. Overall, the disaster caused extensive damage and loss of life in multiple provinces.

After the earthquake, Bingöl, Samsun, and Muş Provinces had damaged houses and buildings, while Kayseri and Sivas Provinces experienced building collapses. Giresun Province had a five-story building damaged, and an unoccupied apartment in Elazığ later collapsed. Notable fatalities in Turkey included politicians, athletes, and community leaders. In Syria, over 8,400 people died, and more than 14,500 were injured, with many children and women among the casualties. The Syrian government and rebel-held areas reported thousands of deaths. Homelessness and affected population estimates point to a significant humanitarian crisis in Syria.

The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported uncounted deaths in Syria that were buried before registration and some victims who died in hospitals. The earthquake is considered the largest ever recorded in Syria's operational history. An estimated 5.37 million people in Syria have been displaced, and 10.9 million people were affected, nearly half of Syria's population. Many buildings, power plants, water facilities, hospitals, and public infrastructure were damaged. Schools, residential areas, villages, towns, and cities were severely affected. Hundreds were killed in several towns, and many were injured. The Afrin Dam cracked, causing flooding and damaging or destroying most buildings in Al-Tloul, leading to the displacement of nearly 500 families. Rescue teams were lacking in some villages, causing civilians to be trapped under rubble for hours.

The text describes the widespread destruction and loss of life caused by the earthquake in Syria. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported numerous uncounted deaths and injuries, with many people displaced from their homes. Rescue efforts were complicated by damaged infrastructure, including hospitals and public facilities. The earthquake caused significant damage to various archaeological sites and historical landmarks, such as the Khawabi Castle, Aleika Castle, and the Aleppo National Museum. The International Rescue Committee noted that the disaster struck as rebel-held areas were preparing for a blizzard and dealing with a cholera outbreak. In Aleppo, dozens of buildings collapsed, and at least 444 people died, including 163 children. The earthquake also caused damage to the castle Margat in Damascus.

The text describes the extensive damage and loss of life caused by the earthquake in Syria and its impact on neighboring countries. In Syria, the earthquake resulted in numerous deaths, injuries, and displaced individuals, with rescue efforts hindered by damaged infrastructure. The disaster also caused significant damage to historical landmarks, including several castles and the Aleppo National Museum. In addition, the earthquake affected several countries in the region, resulting in deaths and injuries among both local populations and refugees. In Lebanon, buildings shook, and residents were forced to flee their homes. The text notes that the earthquake resulted in the deaths of at least 6,600 Syrians residing in Turkey, as well as fatalities among Iraqi war refugees, Afghans, Lebanese, Azerbaijanis, Italians, Turkish Cypriots, and an entrepreneur.

The earthquake caused fatalities and injuries in several countries, including the deaths of 19 students, two teachers, and a parent from Northern Cyprus in a hotel collapse in Turkey. Lebanon experienced building damage and evacuations, with 16,200 buildings affected nationwide. In Israel, a building was evacuated in Ashdod and a tower was slightly damaged in Bnei Brak. Cyprus had some building damage and six beached whales, potentially linked to the earthquake's sea disturbances. Iraq and Egypt also felt the tremors, with minor damage in Erbil and a large crack in Alexandria's Corniche. Aftershocks followed, including a Mww 6.3 quake near Antakya, causing further damage and injuries in Turkey.

The earthquake resulted in injuries in multiple countries, including 562 in Turkey and at least 500 in Syria. In Turkey, there were fatalities from building collapses and stampedes in Syria. Aftershocks, including a Mww 6.3 quake near Antakya, caused further damage and injuries. Injuries were also reported in Lebanon, Egypt, and Jordan. The USGS PAGER service estimated a significant probability of substantial economic losses and a high death toll. Risklayer predicted a potential death toll of up to 105,671. A geophysics professor suggested that over 180,000 people might be trapped under the rubble, mostly deceased.

The USGS PAGER service estimated a significant probability of substantial economic losses, with a 35% chance of losses between $1-10 billion and a 27% chance of losses between $10-100 billion. Risklayer predicted a potential death toll of up to 105,671, and a geophysics professor suggested that over 180,000 people might be trapped under the rubble, mostly deceased. The earthquake caused significant damage to the Turkish economy, with the Turkish lira and stock markets experiencing a sharp decline, and the cost of rebuilding estimated to be around $84.1 billion by TÜRKONFED and $103.6 billion by the Turkish government. The United Nations Development Programme estimated that between 116 million and 210 million tons of debris must be cleared in Turkey.

It's important to note that these are just estimations, and the final numbers may vary as the situation is still ongoing and the damage is still being assessed.

The text discusses the aftermath of the earthquake in Turkey and Syria. In Turkey, about half of the residential properties in the affected area are insured by Compulsory Earthquake Insurance. The UN estimated that 116-210 million tons of debris need to be cleared in Turkey, with a building debris volume of 100 million m3, which is greater than any recent natural disaster. In Syria, the World Bank estimated $5.1 billion in damages, with nearly half on residential buildings and 18% on infrastructure. The reconstruction cost is estimated at $7.9 billion, and the economy may contract by up to 5.5% in 2023. Thousands were trapped under rubble in Turkey, and many people were missing. Officials opened hotels and mosques as shelters, and nearly 250,000 displaced persons resided in schools in Malatya Province. Rescue efforts were criticized in Hatay Province, and the airport's runway was damaged. The damage in Syria is equivalent to about 10% of its GDP.

The earthquake in Turkey and Syria caused significant damage, particularly in Hatay Province where the airport's runway was heavily damaged, making rescue efforts challenging. Many people were trapped under rubble, and thousands were rescued. Temporary shelters were set up in mosques, schools, shopping malls, and stadiums. Humanitarian institutions and airlines launched emergency appeals and provided free flights for victims and volunteers. The Turkish government declared a state of emergency in the affected provinces and urged residents to avoid damaged buildings. The national government also called for international aid. Clean-up efforts in Turkey are estimated to involve removing 100 million m3 of building debris, greater than any recent natural disaster. The damage in Syria is equivalent to about 10% of its GDP.

After the earthquake in Turkey and Syria, President Erdoğan declared a 3-month state of emergency in the 10 affected provinces and requested international aid. Over 53,000 Turkish emergency workers, along with rescue teams from other countries, were deployed to the affected regions. Poor weather conditions and damaged roads slowed down aid delivery. On February 8, Erdoğan visited some of the affected areas and acknowledged response shortcomings, but denied insufficient personnel. AFAD announced on February 19 that search and rescue efforts in most provinces had ceased, with operations ongoing for 40 buildings in Kahramanmaraş and Hatay provinces. Charity and volunteer campaigns were also underway.

Following the earthquake in Turkey and Syria, a state of emergency was declared in the affected provinces, and international aid was requested. Tens of thousands of Turkish emergency workers and rescue teams from other countries were deployed, with over 159,000 volunteers and professionals working in the affected areas by February 11. Charity and volunteer campaigns were also initiated, with significant financial contributions from various organizations and individuals. The Turkish Red Crescent urged people to donate blood. The government announced compensation for those who lost their homes, with relocation assistance and rent support. President Erdoğan promised to rebuild destroyed homes within a year and provide temporary accommodation for the homeless. AFAD announced that search and rescue operations would be largely discontinued by February 19, except for 40 buildings in Kahramanmaraş and Hatay provinces.

After the earthquake, the Turkish government announced rental assistance of up to ₺5,000 for homeowners and ₺2,000 for tenants, and pledged to rebuild destroyed homes within a year, also providing temporary accommodations and rent subsidies for those unwilling to stay in tents. Over 1.9 million people were rehoused in various types of shelters. The government allocated 100 billion lira for disaster response and initiated plans to construct 200,000 homes in the affected provinces and 70,000 in villages. By April, construction had started on 105,000 homes, with 319,000 homes planned for completion by the end of 2023. New facilities were also being built in the affected region.

Following the earthquake, the Turkish government provided rental assistance and temporary accommodations, rehousing over 1.9 million people. They allocated 100 billion lira for disaster response and initiated a construction plan for homes and facilities. The government later announced an increased construction plan of 507,000 houses and 143,000 village homes, with 319,000 homes planned for completion by the end of 2023. However, security issues arose, with armed groups causing suspension of rescue operations by some teams and contributing to fatal incidents, such as a prison riot, a gas explosion, a bus collision, and a tornado, which resulted in several casualties and injuries. The PKK declared a ceasefire and urged all groups to stop military actions, focusing on recovery efforts.

After the earthquake, the Turkish government provided housing assistance and initiated a large construction plan. However, security issues and natural disasters, including a bus collision, a tornado, and floods, resulted in casualties and injuries among earthquake survivors. The government had planned to hold elections on May 14, 2023, but there were doubts about whether they could be held on schedule due to the earthquake's aftermath. Some politicians, such as Bülent Arınç of the AKP, called for the elections to be postponed, but this was met with criticism and opposition from other politicians and media outlets. The government later stated that the elections would not be delayed. The declaration of a state of emergency in the affected regions was also seen as a potential measure to postpone the elections.

Following the earthquake, the Turkish government faced calls to postpone the elections due to security issues and natural disasters, but ultimately decided not to. The earthquake also led to the suspension of education and sports events in the affected regions. Selahattin Demirtaş of the HDP criticized the idea of postponing the elections as a political coup. The Council of Higher Education suspended university education in the affected provinces and used student hostels to house affected individuals. Schools were closed for two weeks nationwide and students in the affected provinces were transferred to other provinces. The Süper Lig and other sports competitions were suspended, with some clubs from affected regions withdrawing from competition. The 2023 ISF World School Winter Games and the 2023 Men's EuroHockey Indoor Club Cup were canceled due to the earthquake's impact.

After the earthquake, the 2023 Men's EuroHockey Indoor Club Cup was canceled, and all national championships were suspended in Turkey. Several athletes, including the entire Northern Cypriot Türk Maarif Koleji's high school volleyball team, Iranian paralympic football team members, Ghanaian winger Christian Atsu, and basketball player Nilay Aydogan, lost their lives. In response to the disaster, fans protested the Turkish government during football games, demanding its resignation. In Syria, President Bashar al-Assad organized a rescue plan, mobilized emergency services, and appealed for international aid. The earthquake's impact led to the cancellation of various sports events and disrupted education in affected regions.

In response to the earthquake, President al-Assad ordered various ministries to provide aid, including food distribution and damage assessment. The Syrian government appealed for international aid from multiple organizations and countries, but logistical issues prevented the mobilization of aid from Turkey. Some hotels, refugees, and expatriates offered shelter to survivors. Overcrowded hospitals faced a shortage of medical supplies and bed capacity, with many patients having to sleep on floors. Volunteer groups distributed food, blankets, and first aid essentials. The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs reported damaged roads and logistical challenges in delivering international aid across the border from Turkey. The Bab al-Hawa Border Crossing became accessible on 8 February. Various facilities, such as sports venues and university dormitories, were opened to accommodate survivors. The Syria Trust for Development announced the establishment of shelters across multiple governorates.

After the earthquake, volunteer groups assessed building damage and provided food, blankets, and first aid. Overcrowded hospitals, already low on supplies, struggled to treat a surge of patients, with many sleeping on floors. The Ministry of Health sent medical convoys to affected areas. Local charities, including Saed Initiative and al-Bir and al-Ihsan, distributed meals, with Saed Initiative aiming to distribute 40,000 meals daily. Over 2,000 Syria Civil Defense volunteers participated in search and rescue efforts, facing equipment shortages. Officials announced the end of rescue efforts in Hama, and over 298,000 people were left homeless. The Syrian Arab Red Crescent requested that Western countries lift Syria sanctions, claiming they hinder humanitarian assistance during the earthquake recovery. These sanctions, enacted by various countries and organizations since the 2011 civil war, include blocking banks and payment processors, affecting international charities and families trying to send money to those in need in Syria.

Following the earthquake, the Syrian Arab Red Crescent requested that Western countries lift sanctions against Syria, claiming they hinder humanitarian assistance during the recovery effort. These sanctions, implemented by various countries and organizations since the 2011 civil war, include an oil embargo and asset freezes. The US announced a 180-day exemption for earthquake relief efforts, but Syria criticized it as misleading. Humanitarian aid from various sources started entering Syria via Turkey and additional border crossings. The Syrian government agreed to open two more border crossings for three months. International organizations and countries, including the Arab League and ASEAN, offered assistance for the post-earthquake recovery.

After the earthquake, Syria agreed to open two border crossings at Bab al-Salam and al Raée for humanitarian aid from the Arab League and ASEAN, who offered assistance. The EU activated its Civil Protection Mechanism, sending rescue and medical teams and committing €3 million to Turkey and €3.5 million to Syria, while also organizing a donor conference. NATO members mobilized support, deploying search and rescue equipment, shelter facilities, and a vessel carrying temporary housing containers. The UN released $50 million in emergency funds, sent humanitarian aid through Turkey, and coordinated responses with various agencies. The UN also appealed for €396 million to help survivors in Syria. President al-Assad met with UN relief chief Martin Griffiths to discuss post-earthquake recovery and international humanitarian efforts.

Following the earthquake, the UN allocated $50 million in emergency funds for Turkey and Syria, with an additional $25 million grant for Syria. Humanitarian aid was sent to Syria through Turkey via the Bab al-Hawa border crossing. The World Bank pledged $1.78 billion in aid for Turkey's relief and recovery efforts. Criticism arose on social media against the Turkish government for allegedly downplaying the death toll and concealing the number of mainshocks. Questions were raised about the enforcement of building codes, particularly in newer high-rise buildings, and the government's claim that 98% of the destroyed buildings were constructed before 1999.

After the earthquake, building codes from 2018 that established quality standards for engineering design, construction, and materials were in place but reportedly not well-enforced. Criticism arose when President Erdoğan claimed that 98% of the destroyed buildings were constructed before 1999, with experts and locals disputing this based on field observations and satellite imagery. Protests occurred in Adıyaman due to concerns about building safety and the government's handling of housing projects. Critics also pointed out that contractors may have bypassed crucial safety regulations, and that the government had previously granted amnesty certificates to over 3 million buildings before the 2018 general election.

Following the earthquake, building codes from 2018 were in place but not well-enforced, leading to concerns about building safety. President Erdoğan had previously granted amnesty certificates to over 3 million buildings, including 294,165 in the affected provinces, potentially bypassing crucial safety regulations. The government has been accused of profiting from zoning amnesty laws, generating US$2 billion since the latest law was approved in 2018. Opposition leader Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu criticized the government's handling of the disaster and questioned the use of an "earthquake tax" meant for disaster prevention. Additionally, some residents have alleged discrimination and neglect in the government's recovery efforts.

After the earthquake, building codes from 2018 were in place but not properly enforced, causing concerns about building safety. The government, accused of profiting from zoning amnesty laws, has faced criticism for its handling of the disaster, including allegations of unequal aid distribution favoring AKP-loyal areas. AFAD, the disaster relief agency, was criticized for its slow response due to increasing centralization and loss of autonomy, as well as for having inexperienced board members. The late deployment of military resources and interference by local governors in aid distribution have also been reported. The government declared a state of emergency in 10 affected provinces on February 9, 2023.

Following the earthquake, building codes from 2018 were not properly enforced, leading to concerns about building safety. The government, accused of profiting from zoning amnesty laws and unequal aid distribution favoring AKP-loyal areas, declared a state of emergency in 10 provinces. AFAD, the disaster relief agency, faced criticism for its slow response due to centralization and inexperienced board members. The late deployment of military resources and interference by local governors in aid distribution were also reported. Residents in Samandağ had to dig through rubble for victims due to the slow government response. The government blocked Twitter, causing public anger as it was used to share information on aid and survivors. The Radio and Television Supreme Council fined and suspended shows on Halk TV, Tele1, and Fox for their earthquake coverage. Turkish police detained several people for "provocative posts" on social media. The HDP and the Hasankoca Neighborhood Assistance and Solidarity Association had their aid seized by the district governor, arguing they could not distribute aid independently.

After the earthquake, Turkish authorities detained several individuals for "provocative posts" on social media, with the number of detentions rising to a dozen by 8 February. Separately, 98 people were arrested for looting and defrauding victims. Syrians in the country faced increased discrimination, with allegations of torture and ill-treatment by Turkish security forces. A judicial investigation was opened on 9 February to hold accountable those responsible for building collapses, leading to the establishment of "Earthquake Crimes Investigation" bureaus. By 25 February, 184 people had been arrested and were awaiting trial for their involvement in building collapses. Additionally, journalists were detained and harassed for their reporting on the earthquake.

After the earthquake, Turkish authorities arrested over a hundred people for various reasons related to the disaster, including contractors, building owners, and managers. The arrests were made in connection with building collapses, looting, and fraud against victims. Some were detained for "spreading misinformation" or "provoking animosity and hatred" in their reporting. The owner of a collapsed building was arrested while trying to flee the country, and a contractor was detained for negligent inspections. Many of the collapsed buildings were constructed before 2000, with poor materials due to corruption in the construction sector. Officials declared national mourning in Turkey, Northern Cyprus, Bangladesh, Kosovo, and Albania.

After the earthquake, several nations declared national mourning, with Turkey observing seven days, Northern Cyprus three days, Bangladesh and Kosovo one day each, and Albania designating 13 February as a day of mourning. Meanwhile, criticism arose regarding the handling of aid to Syria, particularly in the opposition-held Idlib region, which was severely affected. The Syrian government accused the US and EU of hampering relief efforts due to their sanctions, while the US Treasury and UN maintained that humanitarian efforts were exempted from sanctions. The UN was criticized for focusing aid solely on regime-held areas, neglecting opposition-held territories. The SSG-aligned Tahrir al-Sham rebel militia commander, Abu Muhammad Al-Julani, called for more proactive international relief efforts. The UN Under-Secretary, Martin Griffith, acknowledged their failure to help the people in north-west Syria. Aid convoys from the Autonomous Administration of North and East Syria were reportedly blocked from entering the north-west region by Ankara and Turkish-backed forces, and Russia faced criticism for blocking aid delivery to rebel-held territories.

Following the earthquake, Turkey and Syria faced issues with aid delivery as Ankara and Turkish-backed forces blocked aid convoys from the Autonomous Administration of North and East Syria, and Russia hindered aid to rebel-held territories. The UN urged the Security Council to allow aid into northwest Syria. The UN Secretary-General, António Guterres, called for opening all closed checkpoints, and US requested an emergency meeting to increase humanitarian assistance. UN Spokesperson, Stéphane Dujarric, confirmed some aid arrival but mentioned the need for heavy equipment and search and rescue teams. Raed al-Saleh, chief of Syrian Civil Defence, criticized the UN for bureaucratic delays in aid distribution. Extreme cold and water shortages in affected areas raised concerns for hypothermia and potential disease outbreaks.

After the earthquake, hypothermia caused deaths among trapped residents in Adiyaman Province. The water shortage in both Turkey and Syria led to concerns about the spread of waterborne diseases and communicable diseases, as sanitation facilities were damaged or not functioning properly. Many survivors lacked access to clean water for showering, and health organizations warned of the public health risks associated with this shortage. In Turkey, a makeshift clinic in a stadium treated up to 10,000 patients in a day, providing tetanus shots and sanitary items. However, the limited number of toilets and inability for many to shower raised concerns about disease spread. Health authorities in Turkey worked with the World Health Organization to monitor the rates of waterborne diseases, seasonal influenza, and COVID-19 among the affected population.
